name: HD 50499
scenarioDescription:
The HD 50499 Exoplanetary System


Overview

HD 50499 is a star with 1.25 times the mass of the Sun, and 1.35 times its radius. It is located 151.17 light years away from the solar system and is estimated to be 2.391 billion years old, as compared to the Sun which is roughly 4.6 billion years old.

HD 50499 is known to have 2 exoplanets in orbit around it.


Exoplanets in the HD 50499 system


HD 50499 b

HD 50499 b was discovered by the W. M. Keck Observatory observatory using the radial velocity method. Its semi-major axis is 3.83 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of HD 50499 b is 520.2479999999999 times the mass of Earth. At more than 50 Earth masses, HD 50499 b is a gas giant, a planet whose mass is mostly made up of hydrogen and helium, like Jupiter and Saturn in our solar system.


HD 50499 c

HD 50499 c was discovered by the La Silla Observatory observatory using the radial velocity method. Its semi-major axis is 9.02 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of HD 50499 c is 931.74 times the mass of Earth. At more than 50 Earth masses, HD 50499 c is a gas giant, a planet whose mass is mostly made up of hydrogen and helium, like Jupiter and Saturn in our solar system.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system HD 50499, which contains 2 planets and was discovered by W. M. Keck Observatory.
